editorial:
By nishkarsh SolutionFor any bulb , its final state depends on the
parity of the number of divisors of . If has an even number of divisors,
then bulb will be on; else it will be off. This translates to, if is not
a perfect square, bulb will be on; else it will be off. So now the
problem is to find the th number which is a perfect square. This can be
done by binary searching the value of such that or the direct formula =
.For the proof of the second formula you can refer this book page 141
E18
name: B. Brightness Begins
statement:
Imagine you have n light bulbs numbered 1, 2,
ldots, n. . To the state of a bulb means to turn it off if it used to be
on, and to turn it on otherwise.Next, you do the following: for each i =
1, 2,
ldots, n, flip the state of all bulbs j such that j is divisible by i^
dagger. After performing all operations, there will be several bulbs
that are still on. Your goal is to make this number exactly k.Find the
smallest suitable n such that after performing the operations there will
be exactly k bulbs on. We can show that an answer always exists.^
dagger An integer x is divisible by y if there exists an integer z such
that x = y
cdot z.
solutions: #include <bits/stdc++.h>using namespace std;long long F(long long k){	long long L = 0;	long long R = 1e9 + 1;	while (L < R - 1)	{		long long M = (L + R) / 2;		if (M * M <= k)		{			L = M;		}		else		{			R = M;		}	}	return k - L;}Â int main(){	int t;	cin >> t;	for (int tt = 0; tt < t; tt++)	{		long long k;		cin >> k;		long long L = 0;		long long R = 2e18;		while (L < R - 1)		{			long long M = (L + R) / 2;			if (F(M) < k)			{				L = M;			}			else			{				R = M;			}		}		cout << R << endl;	}	return 0;}
